His however, does seem a bit brighter lighting up things at the far end of our 60 foot long install bay, but that's a comparison. With either one alone, things that far away on 1,000 lumen mode is pretty much lit up like high noon outside.

review_title: Use only the proprietary li-ion cell if you charge from USB
reviews:
I wanted to buy another Thrunite TH-10, but apparently no longer available, so I bought this Nitecore.

The bad: To permit charging via a USB port, this light uses a special 18650 cell which has a charge regulator built-in. This makes the cell about 4mm longer than normal, and it may not fit into common off-line regulated chargers. (I doesn't fit mine.) It will function with normal 18650 cells, (I had to stretch the spring in the cap), but if you use them do NOT use the USB charging port. Normal cells will overcharge, which is known to cause mayhem. Better design would have the charge regulator built into the light instead of requiring a special cell. Or just omit the USB charging feature altogether. Personally, I'm sure I'll never use it.
Unlike the TH-10, this one gives you no warning that the battery is low. It just shuts off. Could be very dangerous if I were, say, treading on treacherous ground, or working with a heavy object or, as I do, driving my tractor which has no lights of its' own. to or from the barn. Not good.

Max lumens are less than the TH-10, and it's very noticeable outdoors. Adequate, but IMHO only barely.

The on-off button is awkward, vs. the TH-10. Edit: After 3 weeks using it, the button is VERY awkward. I usually have to take it completely off my head to turn it on/off. Button is almost flush with the case, so it's next to impossible to find it by feel.

The good:
I like the lighter weight and lesser standoff vs. the TH-10. It is definitely more comfortable to wear. I hope I'll get used to the weird on/off button with time. Edit: I haven't. See above.

review_title: It was good while it lasted
reviews:
I got mine at the end of January and it worked great during the open window for returns......but come March 4th the window closed and my headlight hasn't turned on much since.

Apart from only having a few month lifespan the headlamp was well designed save for when recharging an end cap must be removed to reveal the Mini USB plug. With nowhere to store the little piece on the body of the headlamp It gets separated, I finally put a piece Velcro on it and on the headlamp to keep the piece from getting misplaced. The light works fine without the cap end cover So I was constantly grabbing my headlamp to head out without remembering the little piece was suppose to be screwed back on.

I have been a long fan of Nitecore -My two mainstay flashlights for years have been a surefire Lawman plus an early model Nitecore rechargeable.

This headlamp, while it felt in hand robust, really was not up to Nitecore's normal bulletproof standards. I have periodically gone back to the headlamp to give it another chance at charging up hoping It will come alive. I had hoped that its underlying robustness might pull it back to work and something might realign or connect back together and I could have a working headlamp again. That technique worked twice after it broke,but alas, there has been no spark of life in it for too long now to expect light from it.

review_title: It will easily light up my entire yard in the middle of ...
reviews:
This headlamp is insanely bright. It will easily light up my entire yard in the middle of the night. The multiple light modes provide enough options to suit the situation. Headband is comfortable and easily adjusted. Came with some replacement seals and and button covers in case the originals wear out. Turns out the lamp itself has a usb input for charging. I didn't realize this until I removed the opposite cap from the light and discovered a micro usb port. That is a nice feature too, but I haven't tried it as I charge the batteries separately.

The only complaint I have about this light is its tendency to get very hot! On high intensity constant light modes the lamp gets warm enough that my head will sweat. This is somewhat to be expected with such a small package putting out high intensity light. The device actually dissipates the head fairly well. Short of strapping some heat sinks on, not sure what could solve this.

reviews:
This is probably Nitecore's best headlamp (as of summer 2016). It is very bright and has a wide beam to ligh up a large area in front of you. The spacing of the brightness levels is well done. The second level is perfect for walking on a sidewalk or well established trail. I would prefer to have the button on one of the sides as to not have the beam obstructed any when changing settings but this is not a deal breaker. I greatly appreciate that when turning on the light it defaults to the lowest setting as to not destroy anyone with its 1000 "eye scorching" lumens. You do have the option though to turn on the light to the last setting by holding the button down for more than 1 second but less than 2. Holding it down for more than 2 makes it jump to turbo from the previously used setting.

It is fairly comfortable to wear though I have not worn it for extended periods. Since you must completely remove the side cap to plug in the USB I'd rather just remove the battery and use my D4 charger (you can even put the cap back on a few turns as to keep it from running away unlike when using the built in USB). The light stays put at the angle you adjust it and will not move on its own.

It is slightly inconvenient that the special modes must be accessed when the light is off. From off, you double tap to get into strobe and single tap to get to SOS and beacon. Double tapping while the light is on only makes it cycle through two levels.

Overall highly pleased. It will be nice to use this at work instead of holding my MT10C in my mouth. Well worth $60 especially since it comes with the huge 3400mAh battery. Would definitely recommend to anyone needing a quality headlamp.
